text: good morning everyone thanks for being here welcome to day two of the conference my name is Pierre Cesar
Armstrong I'm vice president of affiliate marketing Amazon I've been at Amazon about eight years and I run a
number of the marketing channels and programs I'm also on the board of the
Amazon smile foundation and one of the great things about that job that I get
to do is once a quarter approve all the donations that we make to the thousands
of charities that participate in the program every quarter we write some
really big checks and we write some really small checks but every penny counts towards all the really great
causes that are part of the program and it's a fantastic part of my job I really really enjoy it one observation that I'd
like to make with you this morning I see that there are many many charities that
punch above their weight when it comes to earning through the smile program they don't necessarily have big teams
they don't have large marketing budgets but they use every single tool in the
book to communicate with their existing and their potential supporters I think
Scott Harrison of charity water did this really really well very very early on
the start of what has now become a really really big charity but there are
also smaller charities that we see in the program like the big cat rescue charity in Tampa they're really
embracing social media and a small program itself Big Cat Rescue has six hundred eighty three thousand
subscribers on YouTube three hundred and thirty five thousand on Twitter and their small team works in unison with
the smile team to maximize every single promotion every single event that the Amazon smile team does they even have a
fixed placement on the home page of their website promoting the program nowadays you don't need big budgets or
big teams to get your brand out there the same is true at Amazon we think and
act like a start-up we're frugal with headcount and with how we spend our
money we intentionally constrain our teams because it encourages people to
innovate to think big and to try to simplify and those are really really
important leadership principles that we really govern the company by and you'll
see a bunch of new innovations today from the Amazon small team a little bit later on this morning so I just wanted

he hadn't graduated even from high school he had a 10th grade education but
the truth be known his prayer was answered and he got a job the next day
as a singing toothbrush on the radio so we didn't have television back then guys
that's how long ago it was he got a job as a singing toothbrush he made enough money to pay the hospital

should pursue his passion which was acting and entertaining fast forward he went on to enjoy great

promise the prayer that he made to st. Jude that day so in the 1950s he formed
an organization called Al sac which is the organization that I lead al sac
stands for American Lebanese Syrian associated charities that's right folks
I'm the CEO of American Lebanese Syrian associated charities and I am proud of
it we exist solely to support st. Jude
Danny Thomas created al sac to create to
build st. Jude Children's Research Hospital and why as a Lebanese immigrant
he wanted to say thank you to God in the United States of America for giving his
parents and yes I'm Lebanese my grandparents the opportunity to come to
this country and to make a life thank you
so they said about they said about trying to build st. Jude I'm proud to

they did something absolutely visionary it was going to be a one-of-a-kind

decided to build this hospital in Memphis Tennessee and open its doors in
1962 at a time when our city Memphis was segregated in many parts of the United
States was segregated why did he put it there because Memphis was the epicenter of the
poverty belt of the United States and he wanted to provide access to specialty
medical care to all kids regardless of
their race their Creed their religion or their ability to pay and from day one
in a segregated City we welcome kids from all backgrounds because we wanted
every child regardless of their circumstance to have the same opportunity at surviving childhood
cancer but he went one step further and
he decided to tackle in an incurable disease you see leukemia the most common form of
childhood cancer had a survival rate of four percent that means 96 out of a
hundred kids that would be diagnosed would pass away and pass away quickly that was a disease he decided to tackle
first and the other thing that he did that was absolutely revolutionary was
that he said we aren't gonna charge no family will ever receive a bill from st.
Jude Children's Research Hospital not for the cost of treatment travel housing or food because all we want moms and
dads to worry about is helping their child survive what this means in current
times folks is that we didn't want moms and dads to make healthcare decisions
based upon how good their health insurance was or how much money they had
in their bank account and you see treating childhood cancer means doing things that aren't going to be covered
by insurance anyway because many of these these protocols these therapies
are experimental and fast forward fast forward just you know 56 years later and
st. Jude Children's Research Hospital has taken a survival rate for that leukemia from 4% to 94% today

you can see there's a lot of challenges with that look look the organization was incredibly

iconic brand but why weren't we breaking through so I'm gonna quickly run through

that brand research but I didn't really understand that brilliant brand research we weren't asking the right questions is
what it comes down to and we really didn't understand the data we were using
our research literally to kind of justify our results or to validate the way we had been doing business but we

if they were difficult to swallow so you know if you really want to be an iconic
brand you have to really listen to what people say and then you have to measure your

we we really tracked our brand so we were looking at at you know as we talk to donors or potential donors the
likelihood to donate whether they trusted us whether they were familiar with us what was their favorability

learned some ugly truths and all of that and the three basic things that we learned was people didn't understand us
people that knew us loved us but they really couldn't say much about who we
were okay st. Jude Children's Research Hospital they knew we were a hospital but they didn't know the kind of work that we did
and it was our fault and in our the second thing we learned was that our
marketing was inconsistent and it really wasn't helping to build the brand it was actually harming and as I showed you
that slide of all of our different programs people would create this collateral and it was competing against
each other there was no consistency no clear message that was being delivered by all
of these programs that had program owners who were kind of doing their own thing but we did have one thing that was
breaking through we kind of owned one thing the in treatment child look and people really resonated with that and
the third thing that we found was that our authenticity was off the charts people loved our mission which is really
very simple finding cures and saving kids but we weren't telling our story well so that
leads to the second kind of takeaway here always take the time to get your
story right so you know you want to make sure if you have important messages that
they're actually standing out I told you our main message it has to do with the
fact that no family receives a bill from st. Jude we thought that message was
getting through loud and clear but you know we did more research and we conducted tests
on that message and we were wrong we thought simple was better but the
research told us that we actually needed to make that message a little bit longer and then you know we had to hit not only
the rational side of the brain but the emotional side of the brain appeal to
people's left brains and to their right sides of their brain so what we did was
we modified our noble message and when we modified that no bill message to put
the Y in it resonated so we used to say no family would ever receive a bill from
st. you not for the cost of treatment travel housing or food period but we
didn't have the Y and the Y was because all we want mom and dad to worry about
is helping their child live that made all the difference in the world and
that's why we always say those two things together and that really did
resonate with the public but we needed a second message okay we needed tangible
outcomes to tap into the rational side of the brain and that's where our treatments messaging comes in that also
is very very unique because treatments invented at st. Jude have helped push the overall childhood cancer survival
rate from 20% to more than 80% since we opened more than 50 years ago and then
we added this and we won't stop until no child dies from cancer so those tweaks
really made a big difference and then the third lesson that we learned in this
process was this we needed to inspire and enable and empower everyone to be
accountable to our brand I gotta tell you the first part of this journey was
the easiest part of the journey but trying to get people in your organization to change after many many
years of doing things one way was not easy it was not easy people don't like
change okay and they've been resistant to change but here's one way that you can motivate
all of your employees to be more adaptable to change hold them accountable create goals and
that's exactly what we did okay so we created an enterprise goal everybody at
Al sac and st. Jude are responsible for our brand so your annual performance
goals are based on two things there's more than two but two basic things we all share we all have a revenue goal and
we all have a brand goal that makes every employee that works at the charity
or at the hospital brand ambassadors and we hold people accountable to that that
brand that that brand goal so folks what that really did though that led to a
culture of cooperation and collaboration between our various teams it resulted in
consistency and execution it motivated correct behaviors and our employees
started sharing you know the st. Jude message in this in this very way and then something really really incredible

as they were speaking to the public and it really really resonated and then the
